instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
I have this board that was liquid damaged. The customer said they already replaced the keyboard and battery but the backlight doesn't work and an image can be seen with a flashlight. I have removed the logic board and I don't see any areas with visible corrosion but it does look like they may have cleaned it with alcohol and brush.
I don't have another display assembly to check if the display is the issue.

I measured Pins 1 and 30 of the LCD connector and I got 54.6v on LCD Backlight and 5v on Pin 30. With only the screen plugged in I got 3.32v on <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> and 0v on Pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7747</RESISTOR>(<SIGNAL>SMC_SYS_KBDLED</SIGNAL> / <SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM_KEYB</SIGNAL>).

I'm not familiar with the backlight circuit on these Macbook Pro's so I'm not sure where to measure.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: 54.6v on LCD Backlight means display is not detected. Bad screen, lvds cable or lvds connector. Check them.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: How is that an image appears on the screen if the display is not detected? The cable and connector look perfectly fine upon inspection.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: The backlight pin is open. So either bad connector, cable or inside LCD.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Okay with no keyboard plugged in there was 0v on <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> and I was just wondering if that may be an issue before I try replacing the connector and cable.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: There is no 0v on <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> when you have 54V on the output......

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: I just measured again and there was 0v on both sides of <RESISTOR>R7747</RESISTOR>, a probe point for <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> and Pin 12 of <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> and there was 0v while backlight output was 54.6v. I even measured Pin 11 of <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> and it showed 5.95v so the multimeter is working fine.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Look where <RESISTOR>R7747</RESISTOR> and tell me what PWM it is controlling.....Then look at <CHIP>U7750</CHIP>. But again, this is a dead connector/cable/LCD.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
Okay I replaced the cable and now this working fine. Thanks [USER="557"]MDY[/USER] [USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER]  
This can be marked solved.
